Award.AwardTitle: Project Baseline, a living plant genome reserve for the study of evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to create a national scientific resource: the first genome reserve of seeds specifically designed to allow investigation of how plants respond to environmental change over long periods of time. Seeds will be collected from approximately 80 species throughout the U.S., along with population, environmental and climatic data, and stored at the USDA National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation for future use by evolutionary biologists.

To protect biodiversity and preserve our national resources, it is critical to understand how species will adapt to changing climates. Many species are already changing, as evidenced by patterns of earlier flowering in the spring. One powerful way to determine if such changes are due to adaptive evolution is to raise ancestors and descendents side by side under common conditions. However, the fortuitous conditions that allow viable seeds to persist over time and be resurrected from the soil are rare. This project will create a planned collection of seeds that will allow future studies of evolution in response to global change. With this project, we will create a seed 'time capsule' that will allow future biologists to dissect the genetic basis of evolutionary change. In addition, during the course of seed collection, many undergraduate students, graduate students and post-doctoral scholars will be trained in plant population biology and conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a growing scientific consensus that we have entered a new geological epoch, the Anthropocene, which is defined by the profound impact of human activities on earth’s processes. Anthropogenic change exerts natural selection on wild plant populations which may lead to adaptation or extinction.  Although populations may be adapting as evident, for example, by earlier spring flowering, we do not know if this is simply a physiological response to warming, an evolutionary response to natural selection, or both. This is a difficult issue to study because of the long time scales involved and the fact that adaptive potential may differ across the species’ ranges depending upon population-specific genetic, biotic, and abiotic factors. 

Intellectual Merit: To solve this problem, we amassed a time capsule of seeds, called “Project Baseline,” that is designed to be accessed by scientists at regular intervals over the next 50 years to directly observe how populations change over time. These seeds are intended to be used for research using the “resurrection approach” where older seeds are withdrawn from the seedbank, contemporary seeds are collected from the same original source location, and antecedent and successor plants are grown up side-by-side in a common environment to directly observe evolutionary change that has ensued. The resurrection approach can be coupled with long-established and newer genetic techniques to vastly improve our understanding of temporal and spatial dimensions of evolution and processes underlying it.

Project Baseline was thoughtfully designed to maximize its experimental value (www.baselineseedbank.org). The collection includes 65 species, represented by 10-20 populations sampled from diverse habitats and climates, 100-200 maternal lines per population, and ~50 seeds per plant, meaning that the full collection includes > 5 million seeds.  The 269 sites were selected because they are likely to be preserved for future seed collection (e.g. Long-term Ecological Research Sites, national and state parks, scientific and natural areas, conservation areas). The species are diverse in many respects and include different functional groups such as forbs, grasses, legumes, and shrubs. Some species are well-studied and may be considered wild genetic model systems, whereas others have never been studied. For 43 species, sister taxa are also in the collection which will permit phylogenetically informed comparisons to be conducted in the future. In addition, at 142 sites, multiple species were collected which will allow examination of taxonomic differences in evolutionary response to environmental change.

Seeds are accessioned with site and population data and are stored at the USDA National Center for Genetic Resources Preservation, a world-renowned germplasm repository in Fort Collins, CO. Project Baseline seeds have been cleaned, tested for viability, and are being maintained by maternal line under conditions that maximize seed longevity. Over the upcoming 50 years, biologists will withdraw seeds that represent populations from the past from our well-designed time capsule. Experiments will yield insights into microevolution during a period of rapid environmental change. Using this collection, scientists will be able to leverage quantitative and molecular genetic approaches with unprecedented power to elucidate ongoing evolution.

Broader Impacts: We established a national resource that will be accessible to future evolutionary biologists, enabling them to evaluate genetic changes that have occurred in wild plant populations over time. The scientific community will benefit from enhanced opportunities for research in wild populations of taxa that have not been identified as model organisms. This project adds value to investments that NSF has made to long-term research at biological field stations, LTERs, NEON, and a wide range of university-owned natural reserves by including them in a nationwide “time capsule.” In addition, this project provides a model for seed conservation that is unique among recently established and visionary seed banking programs.

During the collection phase of this project, we developed collaborations with science educators and land stewards at public and private reserves and parks. These included regional school teachers, high school students, natural reserve and botanical garden docents and volunteers, and federal and state agency staff. We spread awareness about this project in public schools, state parks, regional environmental organizations, native plant society meetings, and national and international scientific conferences.  Through these activities, we have increased awareness of the concept of resurrection ecology and spread awareness about issues concerning population persistence, natural selection, and evolution in an age of global change.  The outreach activities have exposed a younger generation to this open-access resource will be available to them at decadal intervals to evaluate contemporary evolution. 

Through this grant, we provided job experience and mentoring to young people who may ultimately use the collection during their scientific careers, including three postdoctoral researchers and numerous graduate students, and nearly one hundred undergraduates.  Our workforce was diverse and included Native American, African American, Asian, Chicano, and Latino students. Engagement in this project helped prepare these students for careers in basic or applied botanical, ecological, and evolutionary research.
